subject: Re: [junit] Need BeforeSuite and AfterSuite functionality
msgSnippet: ... But that still doesn t explain why they have to be static. If they were non static, you could just create an instance and invoke these methods on that
messageBody:
On Fri, Feb 11, 2011 at 10:35 AM, David Saff <david@...> wrote:

> Dean,
>
> The methods are static because they are called before the first
> instance of the class is created, and after the last instance is
> released to garbage collection.
>

But that still doesn't explain why they have to be static. If they were non
static, you could just create an instance and invoke these methods on that
instance.

That's what TestNG does, by the way, although it makes more sense for TestNG
since it's that same instance that will be used to invoke all the test
methods afterwards, thereby allowing you to share fields between your
@BeforeClass/@AfterClass and @Test methods.

It might not be as useful for JUnit, but encouraging people to use statics
in their test classes is problematic, in my opinion.

--
Cédric
